G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: The Court has subject-matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, because the amount in controversy, including property damage and consequential damages, reasonably and in good faith exceeds $25,000, exclusive of interest and costs.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Hampden County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, because the parties reside in Hampden County and the events and occurrences giving rise to this cause of action took place at 123 Maple Street, Springfield, Massachusetts, within Hampden County.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7\u00a7 2\u20133.proposition: This Court has personal jurisdiction over Defendant because he resides in Massachusetts and the tortious conduct and resulting harm occurred within the Commonwealth.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, a breach of that duty, causation (both factual and proximate), and damages. See, e.g., Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly sets out the elements of a negligence claim under Massachusetts law: duty, breach, damage, and causal relation between breach and damage. Although it cites a treatise rather than Glidden for that sentence, the court is clearly articulating the governing Massachusetts negligence framework, which is consistent with the proposition stated. Thus, Jupin validly supports the cited elements of negligence.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u20134.relevant_excerpt: "To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. See J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 11.1 (3d ed. 2005)."

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, negligence consists of a legal duty owed by the defendant to the plaintiff, a breach of that duty, causation (both factual and proximate), and damages. See, e.g., Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146–47 (2006); Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2000).
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss the elements of negligence, but it does not set out the full four-part formulation claimed (duty, breach, causation—both factual and proximate—and damages). Instead, the court frames the plaintiff’s burden as proving breach of a duty to use reasonable care, actual loss, and causation, without separately articulating duty, breach, factual and proximate causation, and damages as distinct elements. Thus, Glidden is not a clean or explicit citation for the more detailed proposition stated.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to exercise reasonable care in the storage, placement, and securing of the ladder kept in the shared driveway area, so as to avoid creating an unreasonable risk of harm to Plaintiff’s person or property.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a child can sue her mother for prenatal injuries caused by the mother’s negligence in operating a motor vehicle. The SJC holds that the mother owed no legal duty of care to her unborn child and affirmatively declines to recognize such a duty. It does not address any duty regarding storage, placement, or securing of a ladder in a shared driveway, and in fact is about the existence (and rejection) of a different kind of duty, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Remy v. MacDonald, 440 Mass. 675, 677\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We must decide whether a pregnant woman owes a legal duty of care to her unborn child to refrain from negligent conduct that may result in physical harm to that child. If no such duty exists, a claim of negligence cannot be brought… We conclude that there are inherent and important differences between a fetus, in utero, and a child already born, that permits a bright line to be drawn around the zone of potential tort liability of one who is still biologically joined to an injured plaintiff.”

Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.proposition: Defendant also owed a duty of reasonable care as a neighbor and co-occupant sharing a common area, including the duty not to maintain an unreasonably dangerous condition that foreseeably threatened Plaintiff’s vehicle.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant owed a duty of reasonable care as a neighbor/co-occupant regarding a shared or adjacent area, including a duty not to maintain an unreasonably dangerous condition threatening the plaintiff’s vehicle. Davis v. Westwood Group instead holds that a landowner generally has no duty with respect to adjacent public highways beyond not creating an unreasonable risk from conditions on its own land, and specifically rejects imposing a broader duty to provide safe passage or alter the highway. The case narrows, rather than expands, adjacent-landowner duties and does not discuss co‑occupant/common-area vehicle-related duties at all.
Davis v. Westwood Group, 420 Mass. 739,.relevant_excerpt: “Although a landowner or possessor typically is not held to any duty with respect to public highways adjacent to or crossing his land, he must exercise reasonable care in the use of his land so as not to injure a traveler on the highway. … In this case, Westwood did not fail to exercise reasonable care in the use of its land, nor was there any condition on its land that created an unreasonable risk to users of Route 1A. The mere fact that Westwood’s facilities used land on both sides of Route 1A, without more, does not necessarily impose on it the broad duty to provide safe passage over the State highway…”

Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.raw_text: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 452–53 (1969)
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.proposition: A person who stores or maintains potentially dangerous objects or equipment in proximity to others must use reasonable care to prevent those objects from causing foreseeable harm.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.case_name: Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.support_reasoning: The case involves a bar’s duty to protect patrons from the foreseeable violent acts of an intoxicated third party, not the storage or maintenance of dangerous objects or equipment. The court articulates a general premises‑liability duty of reasonable care to prevent injury by third persons, particularly in the context of serving alcohol to an intoxicated, known troublemaker. It does not discuss or establish any rule about storing or maintaining dangerous objects or equipment in proximity to others, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc.,.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant, as the operator of a restaurant and bar, was in possession of real estate open to the public for business purposes. It owed a duty to a paying patron to use reasonable care to prevent injury to him by third persons whether their acts were accidental, negligent, or intentional. … Serving hard liquor, particularly to one already drunk, has a consequence which is not open to successful dispute. Such action may well make the individual unreasonably aggressive, and enhance a condition in which it is foreseeable that almost any irrational act is foreseeable.”

Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.raw_text: Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 257, 263–64 (2007)
Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.proposition: A person who stores or maintains potentially dangerous objects or equipment in proximity to others must use reasonable care to prevent those objects from causing foreseeable harm.
Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.support_reasoning: The court does not adopt a general rule about persons who store or maintain dangerous objects near others. Instead, it analyzes whether utility companies owed any duty regarding pole placement under foreseeability principles and Restatement (Second) of Torts § 368, and ultimately holds that no duty was owed on these facts because a drunk driver’s deviation from the road was not reasonably foreseeable. The opinion therefore limits, rather than broadly endorses, a duty to use reasonable care whenever dangerous equipment is maintained in proximity to others.
Afarian v. Mass. Elec. Co., 449 Mass. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ … A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor… Consequently, with some important exceptions, ‘a defendant owes a duty of care to all persons who are foreseeably endangered by his conduct, with respect to all risks which make the conduct unreasonably dangerous.’ … In this case, the plaintiffs contend that the utility defendants owed a duty… to exercise reasonable care in the placement of the pole.”

Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.raw_text: Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 640, 646–47 (1990)
Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure or relocate the ladder—after specific warnings and in the face of an obvious and foreseeable risk—fell below that standard.
Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a defendant’s negligence in failing to secure or relocate a ladder after specific warnings and an obvious, foreseeable risk. Foley v. Boston Housing Authority does not involve a ladder, warnings about a particular physical hazard, or a discussion of how failing to address such a hazard falls below the standard of care. Instead, the opinion addresses foreseeability of a criminal assault by a co-employee and concludes that this particular attack was not within the scope of foreseeable risk; it does not establish or apply the negligence principle described in the proposition.
Foley v. Boston Hous. Auth., 407 Mass. 6.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that the attack by Ferris was outside the scope of the risk of foreseeable harm. ‘There is no duty owed when the risk which results in the plaintiff’s injury is not one which could be reasonably anticipated by the defendant.’ Husband v. Dubose, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 667, 669 (1988), quoting Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902 (1987).”

Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.raw_text: Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 47, 54–57 (1983)
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.proposition: Defendant’s failure to secure or relocate the ladder—after specific warnings and in the face of an obvious and foreseeable risk—fell below that standard.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Mullins is a dissent focused almost entirely on proximate cause, foreseeability, and speculation about how the assailant entered and moved about the premises. It does not involve ladders, a duty to secure or relocate a specific instrumentality after warnings, or analysis of conduct falling below a standard of care in that context. Thus, it does not establish or discuss the specific negligence principle claimed in the proposition and cannot be used as authority for it.
Mullins v. Pine Manor Coll., 389 Mass. 4.relevant_excerpt: "The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969)."

Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..raw_text: Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..proposition: The type of accident that occurred—an unsecured tall ladder falling in the wind onto a vehicle parked next to it—is a natural and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s conduct.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an unsecured forklift and whether injuries caused by an intoxicated seaman driving it were a foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s failure to secure the forklift. It does not involve ladders, wind, or objects falling onto adjacent vehicles, and its foreseeability analysis is specific to unauthorized operation of dangerous machinery left with keys in the ignition. Using this case to support a proposition about a tall ladder blowing over in the wind onto a neighboring car extends the holding beyond its facts and reasoning.
Jesionek v. Mass. Port Auth., 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition on premises which were solely under the authority’s control, would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen who the authority knew had unfettered access to the cargo area. It was also reasonably foreseeable, because of the complexity of the operation of such a dangerous machine, that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area….”

Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.raw_text: Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc., 423 Mass. 637, 639–40 (1996)
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.proposition: The type of accident that occurred—an unsecured tall ladder falling in the wind onto a vehicle parked next to it—is a natural and foreseeable consequence of Defendant’s conduct.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.support_reasoning: The concurring opinion explicitly agrees that the plaintiff’s injuries were *not* within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence. That directly contradicts the claimed proposition that this type of accident was a natural and foreseeable consequence of the defendant’s conduct. Thus, this case is authority against, not in favor of, the proposition stated.
Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph, I.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff[’]s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.raw_text: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc., 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902–03 (1987)
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.proposition: The occurrence of a strong gust of wind in March in Springfield, Massachusetts is not an extraordinary or superseding event; it is a foreseeable and ordinary condition that a reasonably prudent person would anticipate when deciding how to store and secure a tall ladder near vehicles.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.support_reasoning: The case deals with foreseeability of a runaway automobile crashing into a restaurant building, not with wind or the storage of ladders. Its holding is that this kind of vehicle incident was not reasonably foreseeable on the specific facts, and it does not discuss ordinary weather conditions or obligations to secure objects against wind. Therefore it provides only general foreseeability principles and does not establish that a March gust of wind in Springfield is a foreseeable, non-extraordinary event for ladder storage purposes.
Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus,.relevant_excerpt: “Based on the evidence presented, there could be no reasonable difference of opinion as to the improbability of the incident which occurred. … The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the harm to Plaintiff’s vehicle and the ensuing economic losses.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.support_reasoning: The case addresses proximate cause and explicitly concludes that the Commonwealth’s (defendant’s) alleged negligence in paroling MacNeil was not the proximate cause of the plaintiff’s injuries. The court finds that intervening actions, particularly by the INS, were a superseding cause and that the parole decision was too remote as a matter of law. Thus, the opinion rejects, rather than supports, the proposition that the defendant’s negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the harm and ensuing economic losses.
Kent v. Commonwealth, 437 Mass. 312, 320.relevant_excerpt: “[T]he parole board’s decision in 1987 cannot, as a matter of law, be the proximate cause of the plaintiffs’ harm that occurred in 1995.… Because the duty to prevent harm, and the risk created by MacNeil’s release, were transferred to a law enforcement agency that could lawfully be relied on to perform safely the responsibilities it had assumed, the element of proximate cause, which might otherwise have linked MacNeil’s release on parole with his harmful conduct in Leominster, was extinguished.… The Commonwealth’s motion to dismiss the claims for negligence should have been allowed.”

Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes recovery for property damage, economic loss, and loss of use proximately caused by another’s negligence.
Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Santos v. Chrysler Corp. is a products-liability/wrongful-death decision focused on negligent design, breach of warranty, evidentiary issues, comparative negligence in wrongful death, and nunc pro tunc judgment. It does not discuss the categories of damages recoverable in negligence—specifically property damage, economic loss, or loss of use—nor does it articulate any general rule about Massachusetts recognizing such recoveries. The damages described concern wrongful death, pain and suffering, lost future earnings, and personal injuries, not the property- or economic-loss categories in the proposition.
Santos v. Chrysler Corp., 430 Mass. 198,.relevant_excerpt: “The jury awarded $12.8 million in compensatory damages for the wrongful deaths of the wife and children, the conscious pain and suffering of the wife, the wife’s lost future earnings, and the plaintiff’s personal injuries. The jury also awarded $15,705 in punitive damages.”

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85A.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes recovery for property damage, economic loss, and loss of use proximately caused by another’s negligence.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes recovery for property damage, economic loss, and loss of use proximately caused by another’s negligence.

Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were reasonably foreseeable, and Plaintiff is entitled to be made whole by an award of compensatory damages under Massachusetts law.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.support_reasoning: The case does not address whether plaintiffs’ damages were reasonably foreseeable or that they are entitled to be made whole by compensatory damages. Instead, the Payton court narrows recovery for negligent infliction of emotional distress by requiring physical harm manifested by objective symptoms and expressly denies recovery for purely emotional distress based on increased statistical risk of future disease. There is no discussion or endorsement of a general right to be made whole in damages under Massachusetts law in the sense stated in the proposition.
Payton v. Abbott Labs, 386 Mass. 540, 54.relevant_excerpt: "We therefore conclude, on the basis of the preceding analysis, that in order for any of these plaintiffs to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress, she must allege and prove she suffered physical harm as a result of the conduct which caused the emotional distress... In summary, we hold that a plaintiff in order to recover for negligently inflicted emotional distress must prove the following: (1) negligence; (2) emotional distress; (3) causation; (4) physical harm manifested by objective symptomatology; and (5) that a reasonable person would have suffered emotional distress under the circumstances of the case."

Daley v. Town of Watertown, 352 Mass. 52.raw_text: Daley v. Town of Watertown, 352 Mass. 523, 526–27 (1967)
Daley v. Town of Watertown, 352 Mass. 52.proposition: Plaintiff’s damages were reasonably foreseeable, and Plaintiff is entitled to be made whole by an award of compensatory damages under Massachusetts law.
Daley v. Town of Watertown, 352 Mass. 52.support_reasoning: The opinion is a zoning and jurisdictional decision focused on which body hears appeals under Massachusetts G.L. c. 40A and on procedural defects in the issuance of a special permit. It does not address damages, foreseeability, or compensatory remedies at all. Therefore it cannot be used as authority for the proposition that plaintiff’s damages were reasonably foreseeable or that the plaintiff is entitled to be made whole by compensatory damages under Massachusetts law.
Daley v. Town of Watertown, 352 Mass. 52.relevant_excerpt: The appeal to the Superior Court must be dismissed as the Superior Court lacked jurisdiction. No appeal from the selectmen’s decision was taken within the twenty day period as required by G. L. c. 40A, § 21. Inasmuch, however, as the issue of the invalidity of a permit may be raised by appropriate parties notwithstanding the absence of a valid appeal, Brady v. Board of Appeals of Westport, 348 Mass. 515, 518-521, we note that, according to the evidence in the Superior Court, there were defects in the statutory procedure before the selectmen.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Pre-judgment interest at the statutory rate from the date of the incident, March 15, 2023, or such other date as permitted by G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

G.L. c. 261.proposition: Costs of this action as allowed by law, including filing fees and other recoverable costs pursuant to G.L. c. 261 and applicable rules;
